What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A comprehensive review of Chinese culture formation processes and an analytical lens to look at phenomenons and records

So much about lineage, deconstructing arguments, classical Chinese anthropological theory, rituals, soft power in places we wouldn't expect, reproductions of the imperial metaphor, and a survey of Southern Chinese anthropology.

I learn about historical anthropology, and the Weberian understanding of agency, structure, and moral economy.
Read a lot about Chinese history, from rural imperial metaphor to modern urban resistance.
Practice research and analytical skills through literature review, presentation, and research proposal.

The course is extremely helpful to understanding Chinese culture and history, and provides me with the analytical tools to understand other civilizations as well. The assignments help me hone my research skills and critical thinking. Prof. Siu is an amazing professor and scholar.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The could be more recent works of anthropology on China.

Strength: great reading list, great professor, comprehensive curriculums
Weakness: There was limited time for student to ask questions and have dialogues

STRONG: course material, student interest, professor's wealth of knowledge and ability to speak ad nauseum about certain topics. WEAK: wayyy too much focus on South China. The class doesn't touch Northern or Western China at all, and a student dropped the class very early on because of that. Siu just is not familiar with that realm of anthropology, even though the class is called "Unity and Diversity in Chinese Culture." I think there should be an addendum to the title that says "in South Chinese Culture" because very article is about southern villages, southern economics, southern trade, and Hong Kong, which is where Siu is from. It could also use some updates to the material, since a lot of it is recycled from other classes Siu has taught - notably, there is very little different with about half of this syllabus and with that of her Hubs class. Siu could also benefit from using powerpoints to stimulate our brains. She's a great speaker, but it is oftentimes exhausting to have to listen for two hours straight. And that's the biggest weakness. It's never "discussion," if we even make it to that point in the "seminar." Siu lectures for an hour to sometimes even two hours (the entire class length) and then asks if we "have any questions" for her. There's no independent thought, because all questions are directed toward her, and there's never any intra-student communication, and it is almost as if that is not even encouraged. We didn't even go around and introduce ourselves on the first day of class, so we effectively did not know each other's names. There wasn't really a class community.
For the last few weeks, I wish to hear more about the reading material, yet the presentation takes too long.
The strength is that the course is rich with both empirical and theoretical knowledge. Weakness is perhaps limited discussion in class but I do not mind it at all.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, the course is well organized and reading materials are very helpful.
Yes. This is a great course to understand the historical threads of Chinese cultures and acquire critical thinking skills

Eh, depends. If you like seminar that really should be called lectures where the professor's words are the Word of God and you may not depart from her POV, then sure. It is one of the very few Chinese anthro classes offered here and the most comprehensive, but it is definitely lacking in its scope. It was mostly enjoyable, even though sometimes dry, and could really use an update to the syllabus.
Yes, for anyone interested in Chinese history and culture, who also wants to go beyond the political economy and binary perspective.
Highly recommend to students interested in China. It provides a lens that keeps us critical when we look at historical accounts.
